reading_mnemonic: Since this is attached to things, it's treated like a jukugo word, so the on'yomi reading is used here.
You learned this reading with the word 任せる, so I'll leave this one to you.
The reading comes from 構う, so if you know that you know this!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You go <vocabulary>to give</vocabulary> a bone to your dog. <reading>Atta</reading> (あた) boy, Sparky! <reading>Atta</reading> boy.
The reading here is a bit weird. Instead of just being か (it changes to が for the rendaku), it is がえ. Just think that if you want change exchanged, I'm your <reading>guy</reading> (がえ).

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ぱ at the end is the only tricky part here since that isn't a common reading (or the one you learned before) for the kanji. Just think of your ol' <reading>Pa</reading> (ぱ), who is the biggest half-asser you know.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The reading is the kun'yomi reading for 値 plus the on'yomi reading for 段. Combine them together to get the reading here. You've learned both of these readings already, so just remember 値 is ね because you <reading>neigh</reading> (ね) when you see a good <vocabulary>price</vocabulary>.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. But it's got shortening and rendaku going on, so you have to remember those if you want to get it right. Or just know the word seppuku already since it's pretty popular. That works too.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The せつ of 切 gets shortened to a small っ. The はく becomes ぱく.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The readings are 取る and 替える put together into one. If you know those words you'll be able to read and understand this one as well.

This word uses the kun'yomi reading for both kanji, which you might have guessed already since there's hiragana sticking out of both of them. The 取り comes from 取る and the 決め comes from 決める. Put them together and what have you got? Bibbidi bobbidi とりきめ!

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The あつ turns into a small っ, and はく goes to ぱく.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The readings here are all kun'yomi, but this is the first time you've seen the さか reading for 酒, which rendaku then turns into ざか in this word! If you know what an izakaya is already, it will help you to remember the reading, but if not here's a mnemonic to help you:

After <reading>soccer</reading> (さか) practice, you always go to your favorite izakaya!
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You always have <vocabulary>to bend down</vocabulary> to get into your <reading>car ga</reading>rage (かが) because you’re just too tall. You have <vocabulary>to crouch</vocabulary> just to get inside your car garage! Let’s hope you can find a bigger one someday.
The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. This kanji is going <vocabulary>to belong to</vocabulary> you.
The reading comes from 巻く.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As this vocab is identical to <ja>年配</ja>, it's also read the same. Just remember that the <ja>はい</ja> turns into <ja>ぱい</ja>!

The reading is pretty strange. It's a lot like 建物 in that it's read as たて, which is like the word 建てる even though the て isn't showing here. So, you'll have to remember it's read like 建てる but the て gets pushed into the kanji.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 引 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Now that you're <vocabulary>retiring</vocabulary>, you decide to go and spend your <vocabulary>retirement</vocabulary> at an <reading>inn</reading> (いん). Inns are great places to spend your retirement because everything is done for you, and you can just sit back and relax!
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading with 従う. Remember it?

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, but it shares a reading (and some similarities in meaning) with 答える, so just try to think of that vocab in relation to this one!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're starting <vocabulary>to get angry</vocabulary> about something. It's mostly this <reading>ok</reading>ra (おこ). It tastes terrible.
This one is a bit tricky, as it uses the on'yomi reading you learned for 怒 and the kun'yomi reading for 鳴る, so try to keep that in mind!
The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. Nicely done, no need to have <vocabulary>a worry</vocabulary> about it.
The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji, so no need <vocabulary>to worry</vocabulary> about it.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
The reading is 手 plus 掛かる put together. Just watch out for that rendaku.
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
The readings are from 抜く and 出す, combined together. Know those two and you'll be able to read this word as well.
The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Also, it is the same as 抜く.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

You recently learned 捕まる, which uses the same kanji, but this word has a totally different reading. To remember it, just think about how the meaning of 捕える kind of resembles the verb 捉える that you learned a while ago. 捕える is mostly for capturing things, and 捉える is mostly for grasping ideas. So it kinda makes sense that they'd have the same とらえる reading, right?
The reading is the same as 掛ける, so as long as you know that you know this too.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 度 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember them together:

In <vocabulary>preparation</vocabulary> for getting sheared, a <reading>shee</reading>p will sit on a <reading>tack</reading> (したく). This sheep tacking makes it so that the shearing part is nothing! Imagine watching some sheep <vocabulary>getting ready</vocabulary> by sitting on tacks. Yikes. You want to tell them being sheared doesn't hurt and that sheep tacking is worse, but something makes you think they won't listen to you.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The readings come from 春 and 巻く.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: 

In your <vocabulary>spare time</vocabulary> you like to drink <reading>hima</reading> (ひま), an off brand version of Zima.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that ひん changes to ぴん.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help a lot to know the word 比較 as well.
The reading is totally an exception. The reading comes from the meaning, though. Yukata = ゆかた.

What’s the most <vocabulary>dense</vocabulary> thing you can think of? A <reading>子</reading> (こ). Children are so full of joy, you can practically see how dense, <vocabulary>thick</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>concentrated</vocabulary> the joy is.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: An <reading>eate</reading>r (いた) is someone who eats. But, the eater hurt his mouth. So now it's <vocabulary>painful</vocabulary> to eat.
You're so <vocabulary>sleepy</vocabulary> you can't even remember your own <reading>name</reading> (ねむ).
The reading is 着る and 替える put together. The か goes to が.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: 

If you're on <vocabulary>edge</vocabulary>, just eat some <reading>hash</reading> (はし) browns to feel better! And if you're going to the edge of the world, hash browns will probably help you make it there too. Hash browns are so useful!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You didn't learn that reading for 組, so here's a mnemonic to help: 

You start an <vocabulary>organization</vocabulary> for <reading>so</reading>ap (そ). You're all about soap and making it more effective through your organization. So you call it the Soap Organization for Antiseptic Progress, or S.O.A.P. for short.
The reading comes from 結構.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. However, it uses a reading for 一 that you haven't learned yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You dream about <vocabulary>unity</vocabulary> so often that it <reading>eats</reading> (いつ) away at you. Thoughts of uniting your country occupy you day and night, but you can't let them consume you.

You go <vocabulary>to tighten</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to tie</vocabulary> your captive up, and you realize you don't have anything to do it with. Then you see a sheep standing nearby. Okay. You take the <reading>shee</reading>p (し), pull its wool, and tie the sheep and your captive up together around a tree. Problem solved!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
When you have <vocabulary>to weave</vocabulary> the only thing you can weave is an <reading>O</reading> (お) shape. That's it. Just O's.
This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which you've learned already. Go you!

If anyone tries to touch your <kanji>belly</kanji>, that's <reading>hara</reading>ssment (はら). Unless you're cool with it, obviously. But if you're not, make sure to yell "harassment!" when they touch your belly. You should also shout what kind of harassment it is: 腹ハラ (腹 harassment).

Note: This word will often get rendaku'd when it's combined with other vocab, like in ビールばら (beer belly) or 別ばら (separate stomach for dessert).
This is the reading for 見る and 抜く put together.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want <vocabulary>to visit</vocabulary> your friend <reading>Taz</reading> (たず) the Tasmanian Devil. He's your best bro, so imagine visiting him and having a good time and saying you're going to visit him again.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
It's the reading of 貸す and 切る put together. Know those two readings and you know this one as well. Sometimes you'll see this word as 貸切り or 貸切 as well.
Allow me <vocabulary>to lend</vocabulary> you some advice. The reading you learned from the kanji can be used here.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Just as you're about <vocabulary>to spend</vocabulary> some money, a familiar sound comes from inside your wallet: "<reading>TWEE</reading>T (つい)!" It's the little bird that lives inside your wallet and angrily tweets at you whenever you're about <vocabulary>to waste</vocabulary> money on something you don't need. Maybe you should listen to the bird tweeting from inside your wallet a little more.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Do you prefer <vocabulary>to urge</vocabulary> people to do something, or <vocabulary>to press</vocabulary> them to do it? It depends on how you want <vocabulary>to approach</vocabulary> them. But it's all <reading>sema</reading>ntics (せま) because they're basically the same.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

If you are going <vocabulary>to go astray</vocabulary>, one way to do it would be to eat wayyyy too much <reading>mayo</reading> (まよ). I can't think of a worse way to go astray, personally.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading for 迷 is an exceptional reading. The ご comes from こ. Think of the まい as the child asking: "Where is <reading>my</reading> (まい) mommy???"
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also be helpful to know the word 逮捕 already as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is a bit weird. Double kun'yomi, so think along the lines of 長い and 靴 getting added together. 靴 is the reading you learned with the kanji, however. It also gets rendaku'd.
The readings come from the ま reading of 間 and from 抜く.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is the same as 隠す. So as long as you know that you know this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Huzzah!
This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this word too!
The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.
The reading comes from 頑張る.

The reading for 痛 should be okay. The reading for 頭 isn't one you've learned before, however. Just think, every time you go to the <reading>zoo</reading> (ず) you get a terrible <vocabulary>headache</vocabulary>. Must be the animal feces floating around in the air.
